section.title: What is time synchronization?
section.para: Maintaining an accurate and synchronized system time on the computer is vital for team work. Planning and calendaring applications rely on it to track time correctly and notify users about appointments on time. For clustered applications, individual host machines often require synchronized system time for mutual communication.

The built-in hardware clock is not a reliable time source. Manual correction of the system time may cause malfunction of critical applications due to sudden time leaps. Therefore the system time needs to be synchronized against an external reliable time source over network.

section.title: What is NTP?
section.para: The NTP (NTP) is designed to synchronize the system time over the network. Its goal is to maintain the absolute time, and use it to synchronize the system time of all machines within a network.

section.title: How does NTP work?
section.para: When the NTP service is properly configured, it continuously queries and adjusts the system time with reliable time servers. Typically, home computers and other devices connected to the internet are configured to query a public time server on the Internet.

figure.title: Individual devices querying a public time server

section.para: Conversely, desktop computers and servers that reside inside a corporate subnet are configured to query a dedicated time server within the local network. The time server itself synchronizes its time with a public time server.

figure.title: Multiple hosts querying an internal time server

section.title: Implementation
section.para: &chrony; is the default implementation of NTP in &productname;. &chrony; includes two parts:

listitem.para: &chronyd; is a &systemd; service that can be started at boot time.
&chronyc; is a command line interface program to monitor the performance of &chronyd;, and to change specific operating parameters at runtime.

section.title: Operating the &chronyd; service
section.para: The main part of &chrony; is the &chronyd; &systemd; service that runs in the background and synchronizes system time with selected time servers.

section.title: Benefits
section.para: Using NTP to maintain the accurate time has the following benefits:

listitem.para: People can rely on their clocks when following a planned schedule, and applications can trigger scheduled actions accurately.
Cluster nodes often need to follow the same accurate time source to keep their data synchronized and up-to-date.
Using an internal time server to maintain the exact system time on multiple machines within the same network allows for a more secure setup with restricted access to the internet.
